item.title: June 3rd 2022 - a paper on signaling cascade was published!
February 22nd 2022 - a paper on liposomal treatment for epilepsy was published!
November 27th 2021 - a paper on neurofeedback was published!
November 25th 2021 - a paper on depression was published!
July 22nd 2021 - A study with Yamashita lab was published in Nature Communications!
item.description: A study of neural control using X-ray was published in Nature Communications! This study is a collaboration study with Yamashita lab in FHU.

item.title: April 1st 2021 - Name of Department has been changed
Feb 26th 2021 - a new paper is now opened!
Feb 12th 2021 - a preprint on the neurofeedback was published!
item.description:
Resting-state brain activity can predict target-independent aptitude in fMRI-neurofeedback training

Takashi Nakano, Masahiro Takamura, Haruki Nishimura, Maro Machizawa, Naho Ichikawa, Atsuo Yoshino, Go Okada, Yasumasa Okamoto, Shigeto Yamawaki, Makiko Yamada, Tetsuya Suhara, Junichiro Yoshimoto

bioRxiv

https://doi.org/10.1101/2021.02.08.430334

item.title: Sep 24th 2020 - a paper on the dopamine and stress was published!
item.description: Dopaminergic Signaling in the Nucleus Accumbens Modulates Stress-Coping Strategies during Inescapable Stress Wanpeng Cui, Tomomi Aida, Hikaru Ito, Kenta Kobayashi, Yusaku Wada, Shigeki Kato, Takashi Nakano, Meina Zhu, Kaoru Isa, Kazuto Kobayashi, Tadashi Isa, Kohichi Tanaka, Hidenori Aizawa Journal of Neuroscience 16 September 2020, 40 (38) 7241-7254; DOI: 10.1523/JNEUROSCI.0444-20.2020

item.title: May 28th 2020 - 2 papers on the depression study were published!
item.description:
Nakano T, Takamura M, Ichikawa N, Okada G, Okamoto Y, Yamata M, Suhara T, Yamawaki S, Yoshimoto J: Enhancing multi-center generalization of machine-learning based depression diagnosis from resting-state fMRI., Frontiers in Psychiatry, 11: 400, 2020. https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fpsyt.2020.00400/full

Yoshino A, Okamoto Y, Sumiya Y, Okada G, Takamura M, Ichikawa N, Nakano T, Shibasaki C, Aizawa H, Yamawaki, Y, Kawakami K, Yokoyama S, Yamawaki, S: Importance of the habenula for avoidance learning including contextual cues in the human brain: A preliminary fMRI study, Frontiers in Human Neuroscience, 14: 165, 2020. https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fnhum.2020.00165/full

item.title: April 20th 2020 - 2 papers on the depression study were accepted!
item.description:
Yoshino A, Okamoto Y, Sumiya Y, Okada G, Takamura M, Ichikawa N, Nakano T, Shibasaki C, Aizawa H, Yamawaki, Y, Kawakami K, Yokoyama S, Yamawaki, S: Importance of the habenula for avoidance learning including contextual cues in the human brain: A preliminary fMRI study, Frontiers in Human Neuroscience.

Nakano T, Takamura M, Ichikawa N, Okada G, Okamoto Y, Yamata M, Suhara T, Yamawaki S, Yoshimoto J: Enhancing multi-center generalization of machine-learning based depression diagnosis from resting-state fMRI., Frontiers in Psychiatry.

item.title: April 1st 2020 - Prof. Nakano started a new laboratory @FHU
Computational Neuroscience
item.description:
We are studying a spiking neural network model of the reinforcement learning inspired by the basal ganglia.

We have constructed a neural network model inspired by the cortex and the striatum. in addition, it has a memory structure like the hippocampus. This model can learn optimal actions under some partially observable situations (Nakano et al., PLoS One, 2015).

item.title: Development of a novel drug application method
item.description: We developed a new drug administration method that allows arbitrary control of drug in the brain using liposomes. We applied this method to stimulate some particular type of dopamine receptors and measured the effects on the cellular functions. This method is useful for biological research.(Nakano et al. 2014, Nakano et al. 2016)

item.title: Diagnosis of depression using machine learning
item.description: We are applying machine learning to multimodal data of neural activity and blood samples from depressive patients.

item.title: Neural modeling
item.description:
We have constructed realistic models of the brain at the levels of molecular, cellular, and network to understand the neural mechanisms of the learning and decision-making.

At the molecular level, we constructed a signaling cascade model of the medium spiny neurons in the striatum. We predicted the positive feedback loop amplifies the dopamine signaling (Nakano et al., PLoS Computational Biology, 2010). We also investigated the interaction between adenosine and dopamine based on experimental research (Zhang et al., Neurochemistry International, 2018).

At the cellular level, we constructed a multicompartment electrophysiological model of the striatal cell including ion channels and receptors with realistic morphology taken from an experiment (Nakano et al., Frontiers in Computational Neuroscience, 2013).

item.title: Neurobiology experiment
item.description: We used to conduct animal experiments with electrophysiological techniques like optogenetics and patch clamp recordings from acute brain slices and in vivo animals for validation of model prediction and elucidation of the neural mechanism of learning (Nagai et al. 2016, Nakano et al. 2016).

item.title: Neuroinfomatics
item.description:
We are analyzing behavioral/physiological data and medical data from collaborating laboratories.

In our previous works: We analyzed brain activity using dynamic causal modeling during reinforcement tasks avoiding stress in humans. We estimated the connectivity between the hippocampus and habenula (Yoshino et al., submitted). We investigated the interaction between the medial spiny neurons and cholinergic interneurons in the striatum by analyzing in vivo electrophysiological data (Zucca et al., eLife, 2018). We analyzed the behavior of mice related to reinforcement learning using deep learning (Matsubara et al., BioRxiv 2019).
